articles.title: Dowsing Experiments with a Medium - 1929
articles.excerpt: Dowsing experiments with Abbot Lambert and a medium to detect water in Kolokynthou.

content.value: Trying to find water with magic. Yesterday's experiments in Kolokynthou.
Abbot Lambert and his miraculous rod.

Yesterday at 9:30 a.m. the famous water dowser Abbot Lambert, accompanied by the president of the Psychical Research Society Mr. Tanagras, the general secretary and neurologist Mr. Vlastos, and the Greek mediums Miss Elpiniki Athanasopoulou, Androniki Chalkiadaki, Sofia Kana, and Zacharia Soulakioti, went to Kolokynthou to perform dowsing experiments.

The system works as follows. The dowser, endowed with the extraordinary ability to sense water in the ground beneath his feet, moves forward holding two steel strips, which he keeps to his chest, bound together at one end forming an acute angle. When he reaches the place where there is water, the tip of the angle begins to move.

Abbot Lambert went to various spots and confirmed the presence of water. Local residents, hearing the news, gathered to watch the experiments. In one of the houses, they asked Lambert to check whether there was water beneath. After examination no water was found.

Abbot Lambert tested the mediums mentioned above, with small but satisfactory results given that it was the first time such an experiment had been performed. Systematic training is required for a medium to reach the point of sensing the water under the ground with certainty and immediacy.

The following explanation is offered for the phenomenon. Water acts in a radioactive way on the medium's nervous system, which concentrates on the strip he holds—this could even be a small tree branch—and he makes unconscious micro-movements that are transferred to the strip.

articles.title: Our Writers as Mediums - School Experiment 1928
articles.excerpt: The Society for Psychical Research records cases of telepathy, autosuggestion, and premonitions among well-known Greek writers and presents a telepathy experiment at the Varvakeio with Professor G. Katsamas.

image.alt: Our Writers as Mediums - Psychic Phenomena (1928)

content.value: Very curious psychic phenomena of telepathy, autosuggestion, transference of thought, etc., were recently announced at the Society for Psychical Research, phenomena that occurred among Greek writers.

It seems that our writers have strange psychic qualities, some exceptional abilities in producing phenomena that resemble the supernatural. The Society for Psychical Research is now studying these phenomena.
We will recount the phenomena and then add some scientific conclusions—some thoughts showing that our writers are first-class mediums!
We begin with a phenomenon that happened recently to our well-known and distinguished playwright, columnist, and poet Mr. Timos Moraitinis.
One night he suffered from a terrible toothache, to such a degree that he cried out in despair:
— But at last! Isn't there a saint to help me?

At that moment, suddenly, Mr. Moraitinis thought he saw before him the characteristic figure of a bearded saint, with the vivid impression that it was Saint Athanasios. At the same moment the terrible toothache stopped.

Astonished by this fact, and not believing even his own senses, Mr. Moraitinis left his room and lit a cigarette. He had no pain anymore! He then ran and woke his mother to tell her what happened. She listened carefully and explained it as a miracle of Saint Athanasios.
In the morning Mr. Moraitinis woke up completely well and thought to light a candle for the saint who saved him from the toothache. He approached a coachman and asked:
— Are you an old Athenian? Do you know Athens well?
— Yes, the man replied.
— Then do you know of any church of Saint Athanasios? Because I don't remember one, said Mr. Moraitinis.
The coachman told him he knew a church of Saint Athanasios near Thiseio. Mr. Moraitinis got into the carriage and went there.

As soon as he entered, he saw the icon of the saint. He was overcome with amazement and felt chills. In the icon of Saint Athanasios he recognized exactly the figure he had seen when the pain stopped. With tears in his eyes he kissed the icon and lit his candle, thanking the saint.

The next day, while walking at midnight with a friend on their way home, he was recounting the astonishing event. And when they were exactly on the bridge of the underground Athens–Piraeus railway, Mr. Moraitinis emphasized to his friend:
— So, as soon as I enter the church and face the icon of Saint Athanasios, I recognize the figure I saw at the moment of the invocation…
At that very moment he heard a voice that seemed to come from behind the bridge. The voice said:
— Yes! yes! yes!
Astonished, he ran toward the bridge, but no one else was there. He asked his friend whether he had heard the voice. His friend had heard nothing.
Another strange psychic phenomenon happened to Mr. Dionysios Devaris, playwright and editor-in-chief of the newspaper Vradini.

One night Mr. Devaris dreamed of great turmoil, movement, and priests in the house of his friend Mr. Petros Filippas, former MP, in Lefkada. In the morning he told the dream to Angelos Filippas, a collaborator at Vradini and brother of Mr. Petros Filippas. A few days later Mr. Angelos Filippas received a letter from Lefkada announcing that his nephew Michail had died.
Another noteworthy phenomenon is described by the well-known short-story writer Mrs. Arsinóï Papadopoulou.

Her brother, Georgios Papadopoulos, was studying at the military academy in Belgium and was returning to Athens after finishing his studies. Mrs. Papadopoulou went the night before to her sister Eleni Nakou's house to prepare his room.

Because it was raining, Mrs. Papadopoulou had to stay and sleep there that night. She then saw in her sleep her mother, who had died five years earlier, sitting at a marble table with a lit candle on it. She seemed to be eating something, and blood was dripping from her mouth.
— What are you eating, mother? Mrs. Papadopoulou asked.
— I took out my heart and ate it, was the answer.

Then Mrs. Papadopoulou woke up. The night was stormy, and she thought that her brother was crossing the Adriatic at that hour and that his life might be in danger. She looked at the clock: it was one after midnight.
The next night her brother arrived sick and feverish. When they told him Arsinóï had seen him in danger that night, he said:
— I truly was in danger!
He recounted that during the journey, while crossing the Adriatic, he was seized by a violent cough and had hemoptysis. Two months later he died of galloping tuberculosis.
Here, then, we have phenomena that occurred among our writers, which can be explained by the scientific explanations of suggestion, autosuggestion, telepathy, transfer of thought.

In the phenomenon that occurred to Mr. Moraitinis, the final scene on the bridge is explained scientifically as a hallucination, arising from the mental agitation he was in while recounting the strange event of the previous day.

This phenomenon of hallucination is a sign that Mr. Moraitinis is a strongly radioactive individual—that is, a medium. And the first incident of the toothache being cured is also explained as the strong effect of suggestion. The enormous power of suggestion is scientifically proven.
The dream of Mr. Devaris, and the dream and premonition of Mrs. Arsinóï Papadopoulou, are phenomena of strong telepathy, which is observed only in mediums.

The Society for Psychical Research, after much study and from these phenomena, has formed the opinion that "all artists today are recognized as strongly radioactive individuals (mediums), from which their inspiration unconsciously springs at the moments of artistic creation."
Related to this quality is the "stage fright" that artists often experience—an involuntary shyness, a nervous distraction that seems inexplicable.
So we must admit: Are all our artists and writers mediums?
Many of our intellectuals are also mediums. A recent experiment proved that one of our best mathematicians, Professor G. Katsamas of the Varvakeio, is a medium with strong radioactive properties.
Let's describe the experiment.
1. The shape drawn on the board of the B class as a transmitter was mentally received by the students of the class. The shape mentally received by Professor G. Katsamas. (image)

At the Varvakeio, telepathy experiments were carried out between the students of two classes. The B class acted as the transmitter under the guidance of Professor Chrysanthakopoulos, and the D class as the receiver.

A student drew a shape on the B class board—a square with its diagonals—and the whole class stared at it intently for five minutes. At the same time the D class concentrated its thoughts for five minutes with eyes closed to perceive the emitted shape. Then each student in the D class noted the shape he "saw."
That was the experiment. It seems to have succeeded, because most students drew a square and others drew the inner triangles of the shape.
Among the receivers in the D class was Professor G. Katsamas. He too perceived a square, but within it also the figure of a child.
What had happened? In the transmitter class, a student drew the shape on the board while the students watched.
It seems that from their thoughts the image of the student who was drawing passed into the mind of the medium Mr. Katsamas, who describes his impression as follows:

— On the opposite wall I saw a small dark square, like a street photographer's image, and inside it, first blurry and then clearer, the image of a young unknown boy about 11 years old, with a broad face, joined eyebrows, big eyes, holding something like a cup in his hand and with a pencil or something else in his mouth.
After saying this, Mr. Katsamas entered the B class and immediately pointed out the student Filippos Boukas, who was precisely the one who had drawn the shape.
It was then explained that the "cup-like" object Mr. Katsamas saw was the piece of chalk the student held while drawing the shape.
Thus not only three of our best-known writers but also a mathematician proved to be a medium with remarkable psychic abilities.
Source: newspaper EVDOMAS, 01.09.1928, pp. 3–4.
